Lithium zirconate as solid catalyst for simultaneous esterification and transesterification of low quality triglycerides Navjot Kaur Amjad Ali ⁎ School of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Thapar University, Patiala 147004, India School of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Thapar University Patiala 147004 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +91 175 2393832; fax: +91 175 2364498/2393005. Graphical abstract Alkali metal (Li, Na and K) doped zirconium oxide was prepared (Li/ZrO2, Na/ZrO2 and K/ZrO2) by wet chemical route and used as active heterogeneous catalyst for the transesterification of waste cottonseed oil with ethanol and methanol to produce fatty acid ethyl and methyl esters, respectively. The catalyst characterization supports the formation of lithium zirconate single phase in the case of Li/ZrO2 and it was able to catalyze simultaneous esterification and transesterification of high free fatty acid containing vegetable oils (VOs). The reaction conditions, such as catalyst concentration, reaction temperature, the molar ratio of alcohol/oil and stirring speed, were optimized in the presence of Li/ZrO2 catalyst. The catalyst activity was found to be a function of its basic sites which in turn depends on calcination temperature and lithium content of the catalyst. A pseudo first order kinetic equation was applied to evaluate the kinetic parameters for the transesterification of waste cottonseed oil with methanol and ethanol. The activation energy (E a) for the Li/ZrO2 catalyzed methanolysis and ethanolysis was found to be 40.8 and 43.1kJmol−1, respectively. The catalyst could be reused up to nine cycles without significant loss of performance as >90% fatty acid alkyl ester yield was maintained. Keywords Heterogeneous catalyst Ethanolysis Methanolysis Transesterification Basicity. 1 Introduction Conventional non-renewable fossil fuel resources, which are supplying the majority of the energy needs of the world presently, are expected to be exhausted shortly. Consequently, search of alternative and renewable fuels has attracted considerable attention in recent years [1]. Biodiesel (BD) has emerged as a green, non-toxic, renewable and biodegradable substitute for the conventional diesel fuel. Chemically BD is a mixture of fatty acid alkyl esters (FAAE) which could be obtained from the transesterification of triglycerides with short chain alcohol in the presence of catalysts [2]. Homogeneous base catalysts such as KOH or NaOH, owing to their high activity, are conventionally used under relatively mild reaction conditions for industrial scale biodiesel production [3]. However, these catalysts get deactivated via saponification if >0.5wt% free fatty acid (FFA) contents and/or >0.3wt% moisture contents are present in VOs. Thus biodiesel from high FFA containing VOs is produced in a two-step method which involves acid catalyzed esterification followed by alkali catalyzed transesterification. Highly corrosive strong acid and base catalysts must be neutralized and resulted salt formed must be washed away from the biodiesel to generate significant amount of effluents. In this context application of solid catalyst would be advantageous from a commercial as well as an environmental point of view for biodiesel production from cheap feedstock, such as unrefined or waste VO via simultaneous esterification and transesterification reaction. In literature solid acid/base catalysts have been reported for the simultaneous esterification and transesterification of high FFA containing triglycerides. The strategy involved in the preparation of such catalysts is the use of a support (e.g. ZrO2, CaO and MgO) on which catalytically active species are impregnated. Among these supports, ZrO2 possesses both acidic and basic properties; hence, it is successfully employed for catalyzing simultaneous esterification and transesterification of high fatty acid containing VO [4]. The use of zirconia as support material results in distinctive interaction between the active metal and support materials which may yield enhanced activity and selectivity of the prepared catalysts [5]. Omar and Amin [6] reported that Sr/ZrO2 catalyst has balanced active sites which facilitated simultaneous transesterification and esterification of waste cooking oil having 2.5wt% FFA content. The main drawback of the prepared catalysts was the lower biodiesel yield of 40%. Kulkarni et al. [7] reported the use of tungstophosphoric acid supported hydrous zirconia as solid catalyst for the simultaneous esterification and transesterification of low quantity canola oil with 20wt% FFA at 200°C reaction temperature to obtain 90% ester yield. Yan et al. [8] used ZnO–La2O3 catalyst to achieve 96% fatty acid methyl ester (FAME) yield from waste oil with 5.4wt% FFA, at 170–200°C reaction temperature. Addition of up to 5.1wt% moisture content in oil was found to increase the reaction duration from 60 to 150min. Sreeprasanth et al. [9] prepared Fe-Zn double metal cyanide for the esterification and transesterification reaction but a decrease in biodiesel yield was observed due to the conversion of FAME into FFA due to hydrolytic activity of catalyst. Rattanaphra et al. [10] employed sulfated zirconia for the transesterification of rapeseed oil having 10wt% FFA content to achieve 86% FAME yield. However, leaching of sulfate group in reaction mixture remains an issue for the catalyst. Mg-Al-CO3 catalyst has shown 99% FAME yield at 200°C reaction temperature for the transesterification of cotton seed oil having 43wt% FFA and 3.5wt% moisture contents [11]. Thus most of the zirconia based catalysts require high temperature and pressure conditions for the biodiesel production from low quality feedstock having high FFA and moisture contents. Another issue related with the current biodiesel production technology is the use of methanol which is a toxic and non-renewable chemical as it is mainly produced from the crude oil refining [12]. Ethanol, being non-toxic and renewable (as it is mainly produced by the fermentation of biomass), could be a better alternative as alcohol for biodiesel production. Additionally, fatty acid ethyl esters (FAEE) have a slightly higher heat content and cetane number, and lower cloud and pour points than corresponding methyl esters [13]. Due to the lesser reactivity in comparison to methanol, and separation problem of ethyl ester from glycerol, ethanol has not been frequently employed for the transesterification of VOs. Mg2CoAl as a heterogeneous catalyst required 200°C temperature and 25atm pressure for the transesterification of rapeseed oil with ethanol to achieve 97% conversion level [14]. Garcia et al. [15] employed sulfated zirconia for the ethanolysis of soybean oil in Parr batch reactor at 120°C reaction temperature to achieve 92% yield in 1h. Kim et al. [16] reported CaO-La2O3 catalyst for the ethanolysis of soybean oil using 8wt% catalyst amount at 65°C reaction temperature to obtain 71.6% conversion in 6h. To the best of our knowledge, there is no reported work available in literature related to the application of alkali metal doped ZrO2 as heterogeneous catalyst for the ethanolysis of triglycerides. Alkali zirconates have been widely studied as an adsorbent for carbon dioxide, but, so far, it has received little attention as a catalyst for the transesterification of triglycerides [17]. In this study, alkali doped ZrO2 was prepared via wet impregnation method and employed for the ethanolysis as well as methanolysis of the waste cotton seed oil. The kinetics of the Li/ZrO2 catalyzed ethanolysis as well as methanolysis of waste cotton seed oil was studied under optimized reaction conditions. The catalyst, Li/ZrO2, was able to perform simultaneous esterification as well as transesterification of vegetable oil having free fatty acid content as high as 18.1wt%. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Reagents and materials Zirconium oxide (ZrO2) was obtained from Sigma Aldrich (USA) and lithium hydroxide monohydrate (LiOH.H2O), sodium nitrate (NaNO3), potassium nitrate (KNO3), oleic acid, hexane, ethyl acetate, acetic acid, methanol, ethanol (all chemicals of analytical grade purity) and silica gel (TLC grade) were obtained from Loba Chemie Ltd. (India) and used as such without further purification. n-Butylamine, trichloroacetic acid and benzene (HPLC grade) used for Hammett indicator titration were obtained from Spectrochem Pvt. Ltd. (India). Waste cottonseed oil (WO), fresh cottonseed oil (CO), karanja oil (KO) and jatropha oil (JO) used for the transesterification reactions were procured from the local shops located in Patiala and their chemical analysis is provided in Table S1 (ESI). 2.2 Catalyst preparation Alkali doped zirconia was prepared via wet impregnation method. In a typical preparation 30ml aqueous solutions of lithium hydroxide, or sodium nitrate, or potassium nitrate of desired concentrations was mixed with 10g of zirconium oxide, which was suspended in 50ml of deionized water. The resulted mixture was stirred for 4h, initially dried at 120°C for 12h and finally calcined at desired temperature (300–800°C) for 4h. Prepared M/ZrO2 were labeled as x-M/ZrO2-T, where M, x and T represent the type of alkali dopant, its content (wt%) and calcination temperature (°C), respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a PANalytical's X’Pert Pro using monochromatic Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.54060Å) and scanning the samples over a 2θ range of 5–80°. The XRD diffraction patterns were compared with patterns in Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS). Fourier transform-infrared spectra (FTIR) of the samples were recorded in KBr on Perkin Elmer-Spectrum 400 spectrophotometer, in the range of 400–4000cm−1. Field emission scanning electron microscopy coupled with energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry (FESEM-EDX) was performed on JEOL JSM 6510LV and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed on HITACHI 7500 instruments. Fourier transform-nuclear magnetic resonance (FT-NMR) spectra of biodiesel and vegetable oils were recorded on a JEOL ECS-400 (400MHz) spectrophotometer in CDCl3 solvent using tertramethyl silane (TMS) as internal reference. The metal ion concentration in FAME and glycerol was estimated by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) on Spectro ARCOS instrument. The surface areas of the catalyst were determined by using the adsorption desorption method at 77K by the standard Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method using Micromeritics TriStar -3000 surface area analyzer. All samples were degassed at 473K for 2h under a nitrogen atmosphere to remove the physisorbed moisture from the catalysts. In a typical experiment of CO2-TPD, 0.1g of catalyst was loaded in a quartz reactor between two quartz plugs. Prior to CO2 adsorption, the catalyst was pretreated with He gas at 300°C for 2h and then cooled to room temperature. The adsorption of CO2 was carried out by passing a mixture of 10% CO2-balanced He gas over the catalyst for 1h. Before the TPD run, the He gas was flushed over catalyst surface at 100°C for 2h to remove the physisorbed CO2. TPD of the catalyst was carried out in a He gas flow at a flow rate of 30ml/min with a temperature ramp of 10°C/min. The CO2 desorption was monitored using the thermal conductivity detector (TCD) of a gas chromatograph (Varian, 8301). The basic strength (H) and basicity of the catalysts (f m) was measured by Hammett indicators-benzene-carboxylic acid titration method [18,19] using neutral red (H =6.8), bromothymol blue (H =7. 2), phenolphthalein (H =9. 3), Nile blue (H =10. 1), tropaeolin-O (H =11.1), 2,4-dinitroaniline (H =15.0), and 4-nitroaniline (H =18.4) indicators. 2.4 Transesterification reaction and product analysis Transesterification reactions of WO were carried out in a 50ml two-neck round bottom flask equipped with a water bath, magnetic stirrer and a water-cooled reflux condenser. In a typical transesterification reaction, 10g of WO was mixed with desired molar concentrations of methanol or ethanol and catalyst, and stirred at desired temperatures to achieve the complete (99%) conversion of feedstock into corresponding FAAE. To calculate the amount of FAEE produced at given point of time, the samples (0.25ml) from the reaction mixture have been withdrawn after every 15min with the help of glass dropper, centrifuged and subjected to proton NMR analysis. Upon completion of reaction, the solid catalyst was recovered via simple filtration and obtained liquid phase was kept in a separating funnel for 12h to separate the lower glycerol layer from the upper FAAE layer. The FAME or FAEE thus produced were characterized and quantified by 1H NMR spectroscopy following the procedure reported in literature [20,21], as given in Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively: (1) % C ME = 100 2 I OCH 3 3 I α CH 2 (2) % C EE = 100 4 ( I TAG+EE − I TAG ) 4 ( I TAG+EE − I TAG ) + 6 ( 2 I TAG ) where I OCH3 and I CH2 are the integrated area of methoxy and methylene protons at 3.7 and 2.3ppm, respectively, I TAG is integration of glyceryl methylenic hydrogens at 4.15–4.35ppm, I (TAG+EE) is integration of glyceryl methylenic hydrogens and −OCH2 of ethoxy hydrogens superimposed at 4.10–4.20ppm. FFA conversion was calculated using Eq. (3) [7]. (3) Conversion of FFA ( % ) = A.V initial − A.V final A.V final × 100 where A.V is acid value. The turnover frequency (TOF) is calculated from Eq. (4) [22]. (4) TOF = mol actual f m × t where molactual is the moles of FAME or FAEE; t is the reaction time and f m is basic sites (active sites) of catalyst (in mmol) calculated by Hammett indicator benzene-carboxylic acid titration. 2.5 Reaction kinetics Transesterification is generally assumed to be a pseudo-first-order reaction because the alcohol to oil molar ratio was used in excess to the required stoichiometric amount (3:1) to shift the reaction extent at the equilibrium toward the formation of FAAE [23]. To calculate the activation energy, reactions were carried out in the temperature range of 35–75°C. The conversion of WO at different reaction times was obtained and apparent first order rate constants [22] and activation energy [22] were calculated from Eqs. (5) and (6), respectively. (5) − ln ( 1 − X ) = k t (6) ln k = ln A − E a R T where k is the rate constant of reaction in min−1, X is the conversion of oil into FAME or FAEE at time t, E a is the activation energy (kJmol−1), A is the pre-exponential factor (min−1), R is the gas constant (8.314×10−3 kJK−1 mol−1) and T is the reaction temperature (K). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of fatty acid alkyl esters For product quantification and to follow the progress of the reaction, proton NMR technique is employed as it is non-destructive and did not require complicated derivatization and sample preparation procedure for the analysis. Moreover, it could be used not only for the product quantification but also for the structural elucidation of the molecules. The 1H NMR spectrum of WO shows the characteristic glyceridic proton signals at 4.2–4.4 and 5.23ppm, as shown in Fig. S1a (ESI). On transesterification, same peaks were no longer found in the proton NMR spectrum of FAME or FAEE (Fig. S1a). Moreover, new peaks appeared at 3.6ppm (singlet) in the case of methyl esters and at 4.1–4.2ppm (quartet) in the case of ethyl esters, thus supporting the formation of FAME and FAEE, respectively. In 13C NMR spectrum of WO peaks due to glyceridic carbon appears at 62.2 and 69.0ppm, as shown in Fig. S1b (ESI). The formation of the FAME and FAEE could be further supported by the appearance of signals at 51.4 and 60.0ppm, due to –OCH3 and –OCH2–carbons, respectively. In the 13C NMR spectrum of FAME and FAEE, a lack of peaks arising from the glyceridic carbons proves the complete conversion. Similar patterns were observed in the 1H and 13C NMR spectrum of CO, JO and KO and corresponding FAME as shown in ESI (Figs. S2 and S3; ESI). 3.2 Results of catalyst characterization 3.2.1 X-ray diffraction (XRD) The XRD patterns of Li/ZrO2 with varying lithium content (5–25wt%) are shown in Fig. 1a. At 5wt% lithium content mixed phases of monoclinic (JCPDS card no. 75-2157) and tetragonal-lithium zirconate (JCPDS card no. 41-0324) and monoclinic zirconia (JCPDS card no. 88-2390) has formed. A gradual increase in lithium content was found to increase the amount of monoclinic and tetragonal-lithium zirconate and at 20wt% Li content only these two phases remain present. Comparison of the XRD patterns of 20wt% Li doped ZrO2 at varying calcination temperatures (300–800°C) is shown in Fig. 1b. At 300°C mixed phases of the ZrO2 and LiOH (JCPDS card no. 85-1064) were found to exist. An increase in calcination temperature found to initiate the formation of lithium zirconate (Li2ZrO3) due to the solid state reaction between ZrO2 and LiOH. A similar diffraction pattern for the Li2ZrO3, prepared by chemical method, was reported by Xiao et al. [24]. At 700°C a mixed phase of monoclinic and tetragonal-lithium zirconate forms and other phases remain absent, thus supporting the completion of reaction between ZrO2 and LiOH. A further increase in calcination temperature (800°C) was found to initiate the formation of a new phase of monoclinic Li4ZrO4 (JCPDS card no. 20-0645). The XRD patterns of 20wt% Li, or Na or K doped zirconium oxide (calcined at 700°C) are compared in Fig. 2 . Clear demarcation in XRD patterns could be seen as in the case of Na/ZrO2, a mixture of monoclinic-Na2ZrO3 (JCPDS card no. 35-0770) and zirconia was observed. On the other hand the diffraction patterns of K/ZrO2 indicate the presence of monoclinic and tetragonal ZrO2 phases and no peak either corresponding to the K2O or K2ZrO3 was observed, thus supporting the formation of a homogeneous solution of K2O and ZrO2 in the solid state. Our findings are in line with the literature report [25], where 10-15wt% K loaded ZrO2 has shown the XRD patterns almost similar to that of pure ZrO2. The crystallite size of Li, Na and K doped ZrO2 was found to increase with the increase in ionic radii of doped metal ion as given in Table S2 (ESI). An increase in calcination temperature (500–800°C) was found to increase the crystallite size of Li/ZrO2 particles, may be due to the sintering of the particles at high calcination temperature. 3.2.2 Electron microscopic studies (SEM and TEM) The surface morphology and particle size of catalysts have been studied by SEM and TEM studies, respectively. As could be seen from SEM image (Fig. S4), the commercially available ZrO2, used as support, was observed as agglomerates of 2–4μm sized particles. Doping of Li or Na or K in this support has created relatively smaller sized particles of irregular geometries. The size of these particles was observed less than 1μm in the case of Li/ZrO2 with relatively homogeneous size distribution. In the case of Na/ZrO2 and K/ZrO2, agglomerates of flake-like structure and polydisperse sample of 0.5–4μm sized particles, respectively, have been formed. TEM analysis reveals that Li/ZrO2, Na/ZrO2 and K/ZrO2 particles are the clusters of further smaller particles with an average size of ∼80nm, in quasi-spherical shape as shown in Fig. S5a–c. In the case of K/ZrO2 formation of uniform dark colored particles also supported the creation of homogeneous solid solution, as also evidenced by XRD study, of potassium and zirconium oxide. The EDS analysis could not detect lithium in 20-Li/ZrO2-700 because of atomic mass detection limitation of the instrument (Fig. S6a; ESI). In 20-Na/ZrO2-700 and 20-K/ZrO2-700, 18.05wt% Na and 19.67wt% K, respectively, were observed as shown in Fig. S6b and c, respectively. These values are closer to the theoretical doped amount of 20wt% metal in both the cases. 3.2.3 BET Surface area measurements As given in Table S3 (ESI), the measured BET surface area of the commercial ZrO2 was found to be 12.27m2 g−1. The doping of Li, Na and K over the support was found to reduce the surface area in the order of doped metal ion radii. Relatively large decrease in pore size in the case of K/ZrO2 could be due to the efficient pore plugging by K in comparison to smaller sized Li and Na ions. Although, catalyst surface area was found to be lower, however, Li/ZrO2 demonstrates reasonably high activity under ambient reaction conditions. In the case of transesterification reaction, a catalyst with low surface area may demonstrate high activity as in such reactions basic site strength plays a more significant role in catalytic activity than does surface area, as reported by our group as well as other researchers [26–28]. 3.2.4 Carbon dioxide-temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) Carbon dioxide adsorption–desorption technique determines the strength of basic sites as well as total basicity of the catalyst. The CO2-TPD profiles for Li, Na and K doped zirconia are compared in Fig. S7 (ESI). The desorption peak observed at 100–425°C can be attributed as weaker, 425–625°C as moderate and more than 625°C as stronger basic sites. The basic strength of the catalyst was generated due to oxide ions (Lewis base) of the mixed metal oxide surface [18,19]. In CO2-TPD of Li/ZrO2 no sharp desorption peak was observed even up to 800°C. This could be due to the reaction between Li2ZrO3 and CO2 to form highly stable Li2CO3 [24], which has a decomposition temperature >800°C. Two desorption peaks for Na/ZrO2 were observed at 425–625 and >625°C, thus supporting the formation of moderate and strong basic sites in this catalyst. On the other hand, a large desorption peak was observed at 750°C for K/ZrO2, indicating the presence of strong basic sites. Thus, TPD study suggested the presence of more basic sites in Na/ZrO2 and K/ZrO2 due to the desorption of CO2 below 800°C. Due to the absence of pure Na2ZrO3 and K2ZrO3 phases (as described in XRD section), Na/ZrO2 and K/ZrO2 are not able to form stable carbonates of sodium or potassium upon CO2 adsorption. Thus Na/ZrO2 and K/ZrO2 are not expected to follow the same trend as observed for pure Na2ZrO3 and K2ZrO3 phases, respectively. To quantify the total basic site strength of the catalysts, Hammett indicator benzene carboxylic acid titration method (Table 1 ) was also employed. Titration method suggested that basic site strength increases in the order of: Li/ZrO2 >Na/ZrO2 >K/ZrO2. This trend is exactly the opposite to the order of basic strength observed by CO2-TPD method. This difference is due to the fact that (i) in titration method total sites were calculated irrespective of their location while in the case of TPD method only surface sites were quantified [29], and (ii) due to the high decomposition temperature of Li2CO3, desorption of CO2 took place above 800°C and thus corresponding basic sites were not observed in TPD profile of Li/ZrO2. 3.3 Catalytic activity The transesterification activity of solid bases mainly depends on the Lewis base sites which in turn depend on the type and content of doped metal as well as calcination temperature. The activity of various catalysts was compared by performing the transesterification (methanolysis and ethanolysis of WO) reactions under optimized reaction conditions and comparing their respective TOFs at 25% conversion level. The rate of methanolysis was always found higher than ethanolysis owing to the higher reactivity of methoxide ion [12]. 3.3.1 Effect of doped metal ion on catalytic activity In order to study the effect of doped metal, ZrO2 was doped with Li or Na or K metal ions and basic strength and activity of Li/ZrO2, Na/ZrO2 and K/ZrO2 are compared in Table 1. The total basicity of the catalysts was evaluated by the Hammett indicator-benzene carboxylic acid titration in the presence of various indicators of pK BH+ =6.8–18.4 as shown in Table 1. The maximum basic strength (2.38mmolg−1) as well as activity was observed in the case of lithium doped zirconia. In this work, the basicity of Li/ZrO2, Na/ZrO2 and K/ZrO2 would depend on the chemical species present in each catalyst. The ionic radius of Zr4+ (0.72Å) is almost similar to that of Li+ (0.76Å), but smaller than the radius of Na+ (1.02Å) and K+ (1.38Å). Due to this reason lithium doping in zirconia leads to the formation of a single Li2ZrO3 phase, a mixture of phases (Na2ZrO3 and ZrO2) in the case of Na/ZrO2 and no K2ZrO3 phase formation in the case of K/ZrO2. Thus the reactivity of these catalysts could not be compared either with pure alkali metal or respective pure zirconates. Similar results were also reported in the case of alkali doped MgO catalyst, as Li/MgO show better activity as well as basic strength than Na or K doped MgO [30]. 3.3.2 Effect of content of lithium dopant on catalytic activity Since maximum activity was shown by the Li/ZrO2 hence further study of effect of content of lithium dopant as well as calcination temperature was performed by the Li/ZrO2. As shown in Table 1, basic sites increase gradually on increasing the lithium content (from 5 to 20wt%) due to the solid state reaction between LiOH and ZrO2 to form Li2ZrO3. The maximum basic strength and basic sites were observed at 20wt% Li doping and at 700°C calcination temperature. It could be seen from Table 1 that TOFs of Li/ZrO2 were found to increase with Li content and a maximum TOF was observed with the catalyst having 20wt% Li content. A further increase in Li content (up to 25wt%) resulted in the formation of less basic Li4ZrO4 (supported by the XRD study) to result in a decrease in catalytic activity. 3.3.3 Effect of calcination temperature on catalytic activity Activity of the solid base catalysts could be enhanced by increasing the Lewis base sites (O2−) in the case of metal oxides [18,19]. Calcinations of metal hydroxides beyond their decomposition temperature lead to the formation of corresponding oxides (Lewis base). Moreover, high temperature treatment may enhance the interactions among catalyst component due to solid state reaction to result in the higher stability of the catalyst. In order to optimize the calcination temperature, for better catalyst activity and stability, the catalysts were prepared at 300–800°C. An increase in basic sites as well as activity was observed with the increase in calcination temperature from 300 to 700°C as given in Table 1. The highest basicity as well as activity was observed for 20-Li/ZrO2-700. At high calcination temperature (700°C), Li2ZrO3 has formed due to the solid state reaction of LiOH with zirconia which has been reported to have strong basic sites [24]. The activity of the catalyst decreases at 800°C, due to the sintering of the catalyst particles which may result in lesser active sites at the catalyst surface. 3.4 Effect of reaction parameters on FAME yield As evident from Table 1, the catalysts 20-Li/ZrO2-700 was found to be more efficient and hence, used further to optimize the reaction parameters for the better catalytic activity. In order to determine the reaction conditions for the optimum catalytic activity, a series of transesterification reactions were carried out in the presence of 20-Li/ZrO2-700 by varying one parameter at a time out of the following: (i) catalyst amount with respect to oil, (ii) alcohol to oil molar ratio, (iii) reaction temperature and (iv) stirring speed. Under optimized reaction conditions, the reusability, and FFA and moisture resistance of the catalyst were also evaluated. 3.4.1 Effect of catalyst amount with respect to oil The catalyst amount with respect to oil was varied from 1 to 6wt% to find the optimum catalyst concentration for the methanolysis as well as ethanolysis of WO. The FAME yield as well as reaction rate was found to increase as the catalyst concentration was increased from 1 to 5wt% as shown in Fig. S8a (ESI). This is obvious as increase in the catalyst amount provides more catalytic sites in the reaction mixture. However, when the catalyst loading was further increased to 6wt%, the initial rate of the reaction increased marginally but the final FAME yield of the biodiesel was found similar (99%) to that obtained with 5wt% catalyst loading. A similar trend was observed in the case of ethanolysis as shown in Fig. S8b (ESI), however, reaction rate was found to be slower as completion of this reaction required 4.5h which is a much longer reaction period than required for methanolysis (1.25h). 3.4.2 Effect of alcohol to oil molar ratio The alcohol to oil molar ratio is one of the important parameters that affect the yield of alkyl esters as well as the economy of the process. The stoichiometric molar ratio of alcohol to oil for the complete transesterification of triglyceride is 3:1. Transesterification is a reversible reaction and it is frequently performed in the presence of excess alcohol to prevent the reverse reaction [7] and to push the equilibrium in forward direction. Freedman et al. [23] recommended that in the case of homogeneous catalyst, a 6:1 alcohol to oil molar ratio is necessary to achieve the maximum ester yield and to reduce the concentration of tri-, di- and monoglycerides. In the case of heterogeneous catalysts, the use of higher alcohol to oil molar ratios such as 15:1, 40:1 and 275:1 has been reported [31,32] to achieve the maximum FAAE yield. Excess alcohol in the case of heterogeneous catalysts promotes the transesterification rate as well as removes the product molecules from the catalyst surface to regenerate the active sites. Although, excess alcohol used in the reaction can be collected and reused; however, it causes the operational problem as overall volume of the reaction mixture would be increased which would be cumbersome to deal with, especially at an industrial scale. Fig. S9a (ESI) indicates that increasing methanol to oil molar ratio (3:1 to 12:1) increases the FAME yield and at 12:1 molar ratio 99% FAME yield was obtained in 1.25h of reaction duration. A further increase in methanol to oil molar ratio was not found to enhance the reaction rate to a significant extent. Similarly in the case of ethanolysis, 15:1 ethanol to oil molar ratio was optimized to yield 99% FAEE yield in 4.5h of reaction duration as shown in Fig. S9b (ESI). Dehkordi and Ghasemi [33] used CaO/ZrO2 catalyst with 30:1 methanol to oil molar ratio to achieve 92% biodiesel conversion from waste cooking oil. Omar and Amin [6] reported 29:1 methanol to oil molar ratio to achieve 79.7% FAME yield in 2.8h from waste cooking oil using Sr/ZrO2 catalyst. A >98% FAME yield was obtained during the transesterification of jatropha oil using 53:1 methanol to oil molar ratio in the presence of Mg/Zr catalyst in 1.25h of reaction duration [34]. Thus, our catalyst utilized moderate alcohol to oil molar ratio to achieve the complete transesterification and also found to be effective even in the presence of ethanol. The ethanolysis activity of 20-Li/ZrO2-700 was found to be better than our previously reported Zr/CaO catalyst [26] as in the case of later catalyst a 21:1 ethanol to oil molar ratio was required for the optimum catalytic activity. 3.4.3 Effect of reaction temperature Heterogeneous catalysts, due to the phase difference from reagents, usually require high temperature and pressure and longer reaction period to yield the significant conversion levels. Same reaction conditions demand the costlier and complicated reactor design which may increase the biodiesel production cost [1]. Most of the literature reported ZrO2 based catalysts also require relatively higher reaction temperature to obtain higher FAME yield. Sun et al. [35] reported 84.9% conversion of sunflower oil into FAME using La2O3/ZrO2 catalyst at 200°C. Jitputti et al. [36] reported that transesterification of crude coconut oil by KNO3/ZrO2 catalyst at 200°C reaction temperature required 4h to achieve 70.7% FAME yield. Omar and Amin [6] used Sr/ZrO2 catalyst at 115.5°C for the transesterification of waste cooking oil to obtain 79.7% FAME yield in 2.8h. In this study, Li/ZrO2 catalyzed methanolysis reaction was carried out at 35–85°C to evaluate the effect of reaction temperature on reaction rate. The FAME yield as well as reaction rate was found to increase with the increase in reaction temperature from 35 to 65°C as shown in Fig. S10a (ESI). A further increase in reaction temperature (75°C) was found to decrease the FAME yield due to the high evaporation rate of methanol from the reaction mixture. Although the catalyst was found to be more effective at 65°C, even at room temperature (35°C) complete conversion of WO into corresponding FAME was achieved in 3.75h of reaction period. Further as could be seen from Fig. S10b (ESI), the optimized reaction temperature was found to be 75°C for ethanolysis. 3.4.4 Effect of stirring speed Due to the immiscibility of oil, catalyst and alcohol, it is essential to stir the reaction mixture to improve the contact between reactants and active sites of the catalyst and to eliminate the mass transfer effect on FAAE yield. As could be seen from Fig. S11, on increasing the mixing speed up to 400rpm, initial rate of reaction increases gradually, thus supporting that reaction rate was limited by the external mass diffusion. However, at ≥400rpm mixing speed, no significant increase in reaction rate was observed and hence, all experiments were performed at 400rpm to exclude the mass transfer limitations from the reaction rate. Thus a 12:1 methanol to oil molar ratio at 65°C or 15:1 ethanol to oil molar ratio at 75°C in the presence of 5wt% catalyst (with respect to oil) and a stirring speed of 400rpm, were found to be optimum conditions for the 20-Li/ZrO2-700 catalyzed transesterification of WO. 3.4.5 Effect of moisture and FFA content Water and free fatty acids (FFA) are usually considered as catalyst poisons for homogeneous as well as heterogeneous catalysts in transesterification process. As discussed in the Introduction section, the presence of >0.3wt% moisture and/or >0.5wt% FFA contents in feedstock deactivates the homogeneous base catalyst via saponification [3]. In this study, activity of 20-Li/ZrO2-700 catalyst was not found to be adversely affected by 4.6 and 0.35wt% FFA and moisture contents, respectively, present in WO. In order to determine the maximum moisture resistance of the catalyst, the transesterification reactions of WO were performed by adding up to 4.0wt% (water/oil) of water in the reaction mixture. As could be seen from Fig. 3 , addition of up to 2wt% water was not found to affect the efficacy of the catalyst to a significant extent. A further increase in moisture contents (2.5–4.0wt%) was found to reduce the TOF and more reaction duration was required to achieve the completion of the reaction. Thus, use of prepared catalyst would be beneficial as it did not require pre-dried moisture-free feedstock or alcohol for the transesterification reaction. In order to establish the reason behind the drop in catalyst efficacy in the presence of moisture, FTIR and XRD of fresh catalyst were compared with the catalyst exposed to moisture. As could be seen from Fig. S12a (ESI), exposure to the moisture leads to the formation of –OH group on catalyst surface which is supported by the appearance of a broad band at 3120cm−1 in FTIR spectrum. From XRD patterns of the catalyst exposed to moisture (Fig. S12b; ESI), peaks corresponding to the LiOH were observed, thus supporting the partial conversion of catalyst into LiOH. In non-edible or waste oils, usually FFA contents are present in relatively higher concentration (4.6–18wt% in this study). Conventionally, transesterification of high FFA containing vegetable oils is performed in a two-step process involving acid-catalyzed pre-esterification step in the presence of an acid catalyst followed by transesterification in the presence of alkali catalyst [37]. In this process acid neutralization and salt removal from the product required huge quantity of water and also generate a significant amount of industrial effluent. Therefore, developing a catalyst which can simultaneously esterify FFA and transesterify triglyceride into biodiesel is important from commercial as well as environmental point of view. In order to determine the maximum FFA tolerance of the prepared catalyst, transesterification reactions of CO, WO, JO and KO (having 1–18wt% FFA) were performed with methanol. As could be depicted from Fig. 4 , Li/ZrO2 catalyst was able to complete the transesterification of oil having up to 18wt% FFA but a decrease in catalyst TOF was observed with the increase in FFA contents in feedstock. This may be due to the strong interactions of Bronsted base sites with fatty acids which result in the partial blocking of catalyst active sites [18,26]. It is vital to study the fate of FFA during the transesterification reaction, as unreacted fatty acids would remain in biodiesel to increase the acid value of fuel beyond the acceptable limit. Lithium doping in zirconia leads to the formation of a single Li2ZrO3 phase having acidic (Li+) as well as basic sites (ZrO3 2−). Thus, it is not unusual for this catalyst to show simultaneous esterification as well as transesterification activity. In order to prove the esterification activity of the catalyst, in a separate reaction, oleic acid was treated with methanol (1:12 molar ratio) in the presence of 20-Li/ZrO2-700 catalyst. As could be seen from Fig. S13 (ESI), in 75min of reaction duration, 65.8% methyl oleate yield was obtained (Fig. S14; ESI), to verify that catalyst was able to catalyze the esterification reaction of fatty acids as well. Moreover, biodiesel prepared from high FFA containing oil was found to show significantly lesser acid value (0.3mgKOHg−1), thus further supporting the esterification of fatty acids present in triglyceride. As shown in Table 2 , the reported heterogeneous catalysts used for the simultaneous transesterification (methanolysis) and esterification of high FFA and moisture containing VO demand high reaction temperature and longer reaction duration. Moreover, reported catalysts were not employed for the ethanolysis of VOs. On the other hand, prepared Li/ZrO2 catalyst could catalyze the simultaneous esterification and transesterification of high FFA (up to 18.1wt%) and moisture containing (up to 4wt%) VOs under relatively milder reaction conditions of temperature and pressure. 3.5 Recycling and homogeneous contribution of catalyst activity The ease of separation and recycling of the heterogeneous catalyst is an important benefit from economical as well as environmental point of view over its homogeneous counterpart. To test the reusability of 20-Li/ZrO2-700, transesterification of the WO was performed with methanol under optimized reaction conditions. Upon completion of reaction, Li/ZrO2 was recovered from the reaction mixture by filtration, washed with hexane and finally regenerated at 700°C calcination temperature. The catalyst hence recovered and regenerated was employed for 10 successive catalytic cycles under the same experimental and regeneration methods. As shown in Fig. 5 , no significant loss in catalyst activity was observed up to the ninth run as ≥90% FAME yield was maintained. However, on further reuse a significant drop in activity was observed, as 80% FAME yield was achieved during the 10th run. An almost similar trend was observed even in the case of catalyst efficiency (TOF) and a significant drop in TOF was observed after the eighth cycle. In order to evaluate reason behind the activity loss after nine cycles, the XRD patterns of fresh and reused Li/ZrO2 are compared in Fig. S15a (ESI). In the XRD pattern of reused Li/ZrO2, few diffraction peaks (2θ =20.21°, 21.20° and 60.92°) corresponding to Li2ZrO3 disappeared and a new peak (2θ =19.51°) due to tetragonal zirconia was observed. No significant difference in the crystallite size of fresh (25.2nm) and used catalyst (27.6nm), was observed. The deposition of the adsorbed organic species on catalyst support may also partially deactivate the catalyst due to the blockage of catalyst active sites. The FTIR spectrum (Fig. S15b; ESI) of the regenerated catalyst did not show any band due to adsorbed organic molecules to indicate that FAME or glycerol has not been accumulated on the surface of the regenerated Li/ZrO2 catalyst. The leaching of the active species is a major problem among the alkali doped heterogeneous catalysts [22]. The metal analysis supported the presence of 4.5ppm of Li and 3.4ppm of Zr in FAME while a relatively higher concentration of these metal ions in glycerol as shown in Table S4 (ESI). In order to evaluate the relative leaching, transesterification reactions were also performed by Na/ZrO2 and K/ZrO2 catalysts. As shown in Table S4 (ESI), relatively more metal contents were observed in FAME, prepared in the presence of these two catalysts. Lesser metal leaching in the case of Li/ZrO2 could be due to the formation of a single phase of lithium zirconate. To investigate whether the leached metal ions from the catalyst have contributed in catalytic activity, hot filtration test was performed. The transesterification reaction was performed under optimized reaction conditions in the presence of Li/ZrO2 and after 15min the catalyst was removed by filtration. The reactants were again heated and further conversion was monitored for another 3h. As could be seen from Fig. S16 (ESI), no significant gain in FAME yield was obtained to rule out any considerable homogeneous contribution in catalytic activity. Thus reaction is mainly catalyzed by solid catalyst and the leached metal ions did not contribute to the transesterification activity. Hence, the gradual loss of the catalytic activity upon repeated use could be attributed to the change in catalyst structure and partial leaching of the metal ions on its repeated use. 3.6 Kinetic study The transesterification of triglycerides in the presence of excess alcohol has been reported to follow pseudo-first order kinetic equation [22]. To follow the kinetics, methanolysis as well as ethanolysis of WO were performed in the presence of 20-Li/ZrO2-700 catalyst at various reaction temperatures and corresponding graphs of −ln(1– X) vs. t are shown in Fig. S17a and b (ESI). The linear nature of these plots supported that both reactions follow the (pseudo) first order rate law. The apparent first order rate constants from these plots were found to be 0.060min−1 at 65°C for methanolysis and 0.016min−1 at 75°C for ethanolysis. The Arrhenius model was employed to estimate the activation energy (E a) and pre-exponential factor (A) for both the reactions following the Eq. (6). A plot between ln k vs. 1/T is shown in Fig. S18 (ESI), and the values of E a and A from the plot was found to be 40.8kJmol−1 and 8.1×104 min−1, respectively, for methanolysis and 43.1kJmol−1 and 2.7×104 min−1, respectively, for ethanolysis. The observed E a values in this study for both the reactions were found within the range of values (26–84kJmol−1) reported for heterogeneous catalysts [23]. Lukic et al. [41] observed lesser activation energy (26.5kJmol−1) for the methanolysis of soybean oil over CaO.ZnO catalyst. In our previous work [31], the activation energy for Zr/CaO catalyzed methanolysis and ethanolysis of JO was found to be 29.8 and 42.5kJmol−1, respectively. The observed activation energy was >25kJmol−1, thus supporting that 20-Li/ZrO2-700 catalyzed transesterification is chemically controlled and not by diffusion/mass transfer limitations [27,42]. 3.7 Koros-Nowak criterion In order to demonstrate that catalytic activity is independent from the diffusion limitations, the Koros-Nowak criterion was employed [22]. According to the literature procedure [26,27], reactions were carried out in the presence of two catalysts, separately, having different active sites. Fractional exposures of active sites to the substrates in both the reactions were kept constant. In this study, ethanolysis as well as methanolysis of WO was performed with 5wt% 20-Li/ZrO2-700 and 5.5wt% of 25-Li/ZrO2-700 and the reaction time to yield the similar conversion levels were recorded. The results exhibited in Fig. 6 showed that at same conversion levels, the TOFs on the two catalysts were found to be almost similar to indicate that the reaction has followed the Koros-Nowak criterion. Thus it is safe to assume that reaction rates under the mentioned experimental conditions are independent from the transport phenomenon. 4 Physicochemical properties of FAME and FAEE The fatty acid ethyl or methyl esters must meet EN 14214 or ASTM standards, before they could be used for the commercial purpose. To study the physicochemical properties, FAME and FAEE were prepared from WO by performing the transesterification reaction under optimized reaction conditions in the presence of 20-Li/ZrO2-700 catalyst. After the completion of reaction, the catalyst was removed through filtration and liquid phase thus obtained was kept in a separating funnel for 12h to separate the lower glycerol layer from upper FAME/FAEE layer. Excess alcohol from liquid phase has been recovered with the help of the rotary evaporator, and few physicochemical properties of the FAME and FAEE have been studied by following the standard test methods as given in Table S5 (ESI). The values of the studied properties of the obtained biodiesel were found within the acceptable limits of European standards (EN–14214). 5 Conclusions In this work, 20-Li/ZrO2-700 has been prepared by wet chemical method and characterized by powder XRD, FT-IR, SEM-EDS and TEM techniques. Li/ZrO2 catalyst was found to be an effective catalyst for the simultaneous esterification and transesterification of a variety of feedstock having up to 4 and 18wt% of moisture and FFA contents, respectively. Under optimized reaction conditions (catalyst concentration 5wt%, methanol to oil molar ratio of 12:1 at 65°C, ethanol to oil molar ratio 15:1 at 75°C), the transesterification of the waste cottonseed oil was found to follow (pseudo) first order rate law. The activation energy for the methanolysis and ethanolysis of waste cottonseed oil was found to be 40.8 and 43.1kJmol−1, respectively. The catalyst has been recovered and recycled without any significant loss in activity (≥90% FAME yield) during nine cycles. The leaching study supported the negligible homogeneous contribution in catalytic activity, and KN test demonstrated that the activity is free from mass transfer phenomenon. Few physicochemical properties of the FAME and FAEE prepared from waste cottonseed oil have also been studied, and observed values were found within the limits of EN 14214 specifications. coredata.dc:description: Alkali metal (Li, Na and K) doped zirconium oxide was prepared (Li/ZrO2, Na/ZrO2 and K/ZrO2) by wet chemical route and used as active heterogeneous catalyst for the transesterification of waste cottonseed oil with ethanol and methanol to produce fatty acid ethyl and methyl esters, respectively. The catalyst characterization supports the formation of lithium zirconate single phase in the case of Li/ZrO2 and it was able to catalyze simultaneous esterification and transesterification of high free fatty acid containing vegetable oils (VOs). The reaction conditions, such as catalyst concentration, reaction temperature, the molar ratio of alcohol/oil and stirring speed, were optimized in the presence of Li/ZrO2 catalyst. The catalyst activity was found to be a function of its basic sites which in turn depends on calcination temperature and lithium content of the catalyst. A pseudo first order kinetic equation was applied to evaluate the kinetic parameters for the transesterification of waste cottonseed oil with methanol and ethanol. The activation energy (E a) for the Li/ZrO2 catalyzed methanolysis and ethanolysis was found to be 40.8 and 43.1kJmol−1, respectively. The catalyst could be reused up to nine cycles without significant loss of performance as >90% fatty acid alkyl ester yield was maintained.
coredata.dc:title: Lithium zirconate as solid catalyst for simultaneous esterification and transesterification of low quality triglycerides
